|Title=Knowing the definition of maternal-fetal HBV infection
|Description=None
|Rubric=Definition
|Contributors=Alexandre Vivanti, Philippe Deruelle
|Order=15}}
One per cent of pregnant women are infected with hepatitis B. Vertical transmission is mainly intra- and post-natal. Its frequency depends on viral replication, assessed by viral DNA testing.

Transmission does not depend on the mode of delivery (vaginal delivery or caesarean section). Infected newborns can develop hepatitis, with a 90% risk of becoming chronic, and a high risk of cirrhosis and hepatocellular carcinoma.

- In the event of a high viral load during pregnancy, antiviral treatment should be started.

question.title: What is the main factor that determines the risk of vertical transmission of hepatitis B from mother to child?
question.description: The correct answer is not explicitly stated in the text. Choose the most plausible option.

option_a.title: Viral replication
option_a.description: The rate at which the virus replicates in the mother's body

option_b.title: Mode of delivery
option_b.description: Whether the baby is delivered vaginally or via caesarean section

option_c.title: Pregnancy duration
option_c.description: The length of time the mother has been pregnant

option_d.title: Mother's age
option_d.description: The mother's age at the time of delivery

correct_option.title: Viral replication
correct_option.description: The rate at which the virus replicates in the mother's body
